answer:
<p>A <code>null</code> pointer is one that points to nowhere.  When you dereference a pointer <code>p</code>, you say "give me the data at the location stored in "p".  When <code>p</code> is a <code>null</code> pointer, the location stored in <code>p</code> is <code>nowhere</code>, you're saying "give me the data at the location 'nowhere'".  Obviously, it can't do this, so it throws a <code>null pointer exception</code>.</p>

<p>In general, it's because something hasn't been initialized properly.</p>
data.title: What is a NullPointerException, and how do I fix it?
